tags.name: Edge Definition Metadata APIs
tags.description: Edge Definitions are required for the system to know what edges are allowed between live node data

tags.name: Metrics APIs
tags.description: Set of operations metrics in a secure data zone

tags.name: Job Manager APIs
tags.description: Platform support asynchronous jobs, and these endpoints allow for the creation, status, and management of these jobs

tags.name: Dictionary Metadata APIs
tags.description: Dictionaries are schemas essentially, they describe the data allowed within a Node of a LifeGraph (can be thought of as a record too); a Node in the LG is akin to a Smart Data Object

tags.name: DbSchema APIs
tags.description: DbSchema is an alternative method to define the dictionaries of the SDZ; it is a 3rd party tool https://dbschema.com/

tags.name: Wallet APIs
tags.description: For interacting with wallets when the type of wallet (user or system) is unknown

tags.name: Data Pipeline JS Transform Step APIs
tags.description: JS Transform  Step is a step used in Data Pipelines and is used to transform fields

tags.name: BlastAI APIs
tags.description: Set of operations for Blast AI

tags.name: Ingest Pipeline APIs
tags.description: Ingest Pipelines are managed for use of manipulating data on ingest

tags.name: System Wallet APIs
tags.description: System wallets are used for non-humans to perform functions in the platform; ie custodian, etc

tags.name: Data Pipeline Field Mapping Step APIs
tags.description: Field Mapping Step is a step used in Data Pipelines and is used to map fields

tags.name: User Group APIs
tags.description: User Groups are ways of identifying groups of users by name and referencing in various parts of the platform

tags.name: SDZ Specific Term APIs
tags.description: Terms are managed for the developer's use to find, present terms to users and records acceptance

tags.name: Customer Directory APIs
tags.description: Manages all customers and their Secure Data Zones

tags.name: OData v4 APIs
tags.description: Reference OData v4 documentation for usage: https://www.odata.org/getting-started/

tags.name: Graph Chain APIs
tags.description: In basic terms, these endpoints are the CRUD+T operations for transactional data on the platform

tags.name: User Wallet APIs
tags.description: For managing and obtaining information about user wallets

tags.name: Glossary Metadata APIs
tags.description: Glossary items hold no actual function in the secure data zone, merely a method for defining the business terms, usage, interactions, etc of the data within the SDZ

Allowed user roles:
  • sdzUser


Revert an SDO by sdo id to the previous SDO. To revert an sdo, the following must be true: 1. The current sdo must be the result of an UPDATE or a TRANSFER, 2. You must be the signer of the current sdo. 3. You must be an owner of the previous sdo. 4. The revert must happen within 30 seconds of the update/transfer of the current sdo. The revert will remove the previous version of the sdo in history and make it the current sdo. The sdo reverted is not put into history. All manual edge and blob changes made between the pervious and current sdo will need to be handled manually. Auto edges will update automatically.

get.description:
Allowed user roles:
  • sdzAdmin
  • sdzReadOnly
  • sdzUser


query ingest pipelines from the secure data zone

post.description:
Allowed user roles:
  • sdzAdmin


Create a ingest pipeline in the secure data zone. For all the details, see the Dev Docs! An ingest pipeline is a series of steps (at least 1) that GraphChain will process inbound data through. These steps are of 3 types: Field Mapping, JavaScript Transform, and Rules. The input to the first step is the full record of the inbound data. The output of that step is then the input into the next step and so forth. The structure of an ingest pipeline is name and steps (required) with an optional description field. This is the basic structure: 
{
  "name": "testPipeline",
  "description": "a test pipeline",
  "steps": [ ... ]
}
The steps is an array of objects where the objects of these three types. * Field Mapping * JS Transform * Rules This typically is the order of simplest to most complex of steps. Each subsequent step in the list is capable of performing the functions of the previous steps. It is up to the admin (or developer) to decide the best tool for the job. Field Mapping This step will rename inbound field names into the field (attribute) names expected by the dictionary. Can rename nested attributes too, using a dot path notation. Not all fields must be in the map; if the inbound field name is already correct it can be omitted from the map. If a field is in the map but the value is NULL then it will be removed from the inbound data. The step has a required map field and type field (FIELD_MAPPING). The name and description fields are optional, the exist to help the user with documentation. 
{
  "name": "demographics mapping",
  "description": "step for name and ssn",
  "type": "FIELD_MAPPING",
  "map": {
    "fname": "firstName",
    "lname": "lastName",
    "dateofbirth": "dob",
    "ssan": "ssn",
    "phonetype": "phone.type",
    "phonenum": "phone.number"
  }
}
JS Transform This step will take the entire inbound data record as the only argument to a function. That function needs to return a JS dictionary (object) as the return value. The type (JS_TRANSFORM) and jsBase64 fields are required. The JavaScript can contain more than 1 function if that helps the developer, but there must be one function that is the entry point of the transform. If the developer names that function "xform" then the funcName field is not required (since it defaults to xform). In this case the JS has a function called "convert" that should be called. The name and description fields are optional for this step just like Field Mapping (omitted here for example). 
{
  "type": "JS_TRANSFORM",
  "funcName": "convert",
  "jsBase64": "ZnVuY3Rpb24geGZvxMjMuNDU7CiAgcmV0dXJuIGluRG9jOwp9Cg=="
}
Rules The final step available is a Drools Rule Set that is executed. This rule set can be used for numerous use-cases: field mapping, transforming data, applying data quality rules, rejecting or tagging data as issues. The type and ruleSetBase64 are the 2 required fields for this step (with name and description optional, just like the other steps). 
{
  "type": "RULES",
  "ruleSetBase64": "ZnVuY3Rpb24geGZvxMjMuNDU7CiAgcmV0dXJuIGluRG9jOwp9Cg=="
}
